Richard (aka Dick) Swann (Feb. 2024)

Richard (aka Dick) C.G. Swann died of cancer after a short illness on 2nd February, aged 87. Dick originally worked at STC Ilminster in Henry Wolfson’s group, which moved to the newly opened STL in 1959. He worked for many facilities of ITT, as described in the his article The Birth of Glow Discharge Chemistry published on the QCC website.

Pete Graves

David Scott (1947-2021)

David headed up the finance department at STL during the mid 1980s, as part of a long career with ITT, STC and eventually Nortel. He was a key member of the management team during this quite turbulent period, being more than just the person who kept the books in order. He was always interested in the evolution of the technologies and actively engaged in the strategic and business development. As such he is remembered by many people as a helpful and energetic supporter of our activities, as well as injecting some valued humour into our days.

David was born in Sunderland and as a youngster enjoyed helping in the family business which involved delivering water to boats on the river Wear. He started a lifelong love of music, playing the euphonium in the Salvation Army. After studying Economics at Reading, starting work in Newcastle, he soon joined ITT to work in Brussels, followed by three years in Basel, which also included a great deal of travelling, including to Africa. Seeing new countries and cultures remained one of his enthusiasms throughout life.

Returning to the UK in 1983 started the spell at STL, which was followed by a succession of posts for STC, Cogent and Nortel, including a period running the cable factory in Newport, and another seconded to the Nortel operation in Turkey. During the time in the UK, David worked on extending his hobbies to include windsurfing and then sailing, and with typical commitment, studied hard to achieve a day-skipper qualification, leading to holidays afloat with his family. He also enjoyed taking part in sailing weekends at as part of the Alex Bell ‘Government Liaison’ operation.

Returning to England when he was 54 he decided to take early retirement and this unleashed enthusiasm for a second academic career. Starting with a masters in Economics at SOAS in London, this would lead later to a PhD which engaged his love of adventurous travelling by being based on a year’s research in Kyrgyzstan – ‘The Management of Public Services in Central Asia’.

Retirement also allowed more time for his commitments to the community and charities in Bishop’s Stortford. He had been a member of the Stort Valley Rotary Club for many years, including three spells as President and he also was Chairman of the Grove Cottage centre for 10 years. In both cases his business experience and strategic thinking were invaluable.

More recently he was a trustee of the local food bank.

With more time on his hands he indulged his other interests such as playing the saxophone, magic tricks, and never without an insightful opinion on so many topics, he engaged his pull towards intellectual stimulation by joining Chatham House, Clare Hall and Rusi.

David will be sorely missed by his family and the many friends he made at work and in the community.

BRIAN CRANFIELD, 1942 – Nov. 2021

Brian graduated in Polymer Science and Technology, at South Bank Polytechnic, and joined the STL Plastics Laboratory (in K1-26, run by Eric Simpson) in 1966, working on the development of polymers for telephone and power cables, and also components. He left in 1968 to work in the map room of the Royal Geographical Society, reflecting his interest in travel throughout the world.

Brian returned to STL in 1971, to continue work on polymers. He also collaborated with John Bury, working on low smoke zero halogen (LSZH) fire-resistant materials for use in cable applications, to create a material that would replace halogen-containing polymers such as chlorinated polyethylene and PVC. Although these materials were fire retardant, they could produce copious amount of toxic/acidic smoke when burning, which could obscure escape routes and injure people’s airways. Heavily filled polymers were developed that could be manufactured and processed on existing equipment with only minor modification, and eventually the materials were licensed for production and worldwide distribution through a major Scandinavian polyethylene manufacturer. The base version of this compound was thermoplastic, but Brian and John also developed a water curable version, specifically for use in transportation environments such as shipboard. This version was very robust and would survive harsh treatment in its working life. However, when patenting this version, a problem was encountered with the Ministry of Defence, who prevented release of the patent for strategic reasons.

Brian’s main research work was on the fundamental properties of polymers materials:

degradation, longevity, compatibility, combustion/ flammability testing, morphology and rheology, to replace oil-impregnated paper in power cables in the medium to high voltage range. The work was based on cross-linked polyethylene insulation, XLPE, and its electrical degradation through the formation of what was known as ‘water treeing’. Unfortunately the work used dicumyl peroxide that has a lingering smell, which was compounded by the smell of crude oil used in work investigating the application of Hytrel polymer in under-sea pipelines for STC Greenwich.

After the work on high voltage finished, Brian and his team investigated the breakdown mechanisms of cable failures with time. Using various techniques they would analyse the results using Wiebull statistics to predict failure rate/time and mechanism. Brian’s later work in the Cable Group was concerned with plastic coating of fibres and making the first landline optical cables, involving different coatings and process conditions. In 1992 the work was transferred to the Optical Fibre Programme Unit and he took on the role of Quality Prime, so becoming a member of the ATC ISO9001 Implementation Team managed by Pete Graves. The Team comprised Quality Primes for each of the ATC Programme Units, and it developed a Quality Management System applicable to the disparate technologies in the ATC. ISO9001 accreditation was achieved in 1993.

In 1995 Brian joined Alan Berry in the HITS group, whose task was to reduce the costs and rationalise the provision of IT in the Labs. Brian’s role was to manage and consolidate information and records to enable cross-charging of costs to the Lab. Business Units. This was a challenging task as this function did not exist, as each group had absorbed some of the costs/details within their own Unit. As Brian built up the inventory of IT services and hardware it became apparent that there were 2.7 workstations per employee. A programme to reduce this number was challenging, as many workstations were part of lab. equipment used for development, control and testing, and so could not be counted in the traditional IS framework. Eventually a figure of 1.2 workstations per employee was achieved. During his time with HITS, Brian also continued in his Quality Prime role.

In 2001 Brian retired from the Labs and spent a lot of his time travelling the world, mainly the Far East. He regularly attended the annual reunion luncheon of the ISO Team, where he recounted some of the hair-raising experience on his travels.

Brian died on 23rd November 2021 after a long battle with pancreatic cancer.

Throughout his career in polymers, Brian was committed to helping young people develop in the materials and cable sector. He worked closely with a number of universities and on summer or sandwich students to give them practical experience. Some names are:

Sue Wolfe (Autonomy & Aerospace, Welsh Gov’t), Lak Bhakar (who went on to become a senior figure in BT), John Matweijew (now a manager at TWI), Marion Beaver (now an energy efficiency consultant), Simon Rowland (a Professor at Manchester University), and John Fothergill and Len Dissado (both Professors at Leicester University).

Brian really did have a lasting impact on their successful careers. One comment about Brian was that he was always approachable, pleasant, helpful and easy to talk to.

Anecdotes concerning Brian:

– As a young engineer he had a purpose built rheometer, a noisy, piece of equipment that was almost always in use during the morning coffee break, to the annoyance of his colleagues.

– On his business trips he travelled light, with all his luggage in a small duffle bag, which was Brian’s way of saying he did not like to check his baggage into the aircraft hold in case of loss.

– Once when he went to the US an Immigration Officer told him that he couldn’t take in the apple that was in his pocket. So he said “Just a minute,” took it out and ate it!

Compiled by Pete Graves, based on inputs from: Sue Wolfe, John Bury and Alan Berry.

Professor Ken Cattermole, 22nd May 1923 – 21st July 2021

Chris Cook wtites – It was with great sadness that I received the news of Ken Cattermole’s death.

Whilst still an undergraduate I was interviewed by Ken and his colleague Harold Wood in March 1962 for a possible position as a Graduate Research Engineer at STL, a position to which I was later appointed. Initially I worked on high-speed PCM, then part of the Long-Haul Waveguide Group in Len Lewin’s empire, but later, following the demise of long-haul waveguide, all the PCM work was brought together under Ken Cattermole in a new R674 Department. Ken proved to be an inspirational Head-of-Department, encouraging and supporting the development of my research skills.

Unfortunately Ken was eventually elevated to the Advanced Planning Group: the loss of such an accomplished mentor led me to leave STL in 1968 for the bright lights of the Independent Television Authority (ITA) who were at that time busy expanding to handle the introduction of 625-line colour TV broadcasting. I have fond memories of those years at STL, and especially of Ken who encouraged my interests in advanced mathematics and in telecommunications research.

Norman (Nobby) Denton – 24th Jan 2021

Norman (Nobby) passed away in PA hospital on Sunday 24th January, aged 84.

In recent times he had suffered uncomplainingly with respiratory issues which left him vulnerable when he was hospitalized two weeks ago with pneumonia and diagnosed with Covid. Ann was able to be with him when he passed, and both his son Simon and daughter Emma were able to visit shortly before. He also leaves two other sons: Mark and Clive, and three grandchildren: Violet, Indie and Aaron.

Nobby initially joined the Mechanical Engineering Workshop team on the London Road site in 1967. He briefly left some years later to try his hand as a publican before returning to join the Optical Communications group under Phil Black. He was a mainstay of the process equipment engineering capability of the Optical Fibre group when I first worked with him in the early 80’s, part way through his long career spanning all the company name changes: ITT/STL/STC/BNR/NT/Nortel; eventually retiring at 65 in 2001. He actually wanted to stay on, but it was against company policy at the time.

He was key to the design and fabrication of the initial and subsequent generations of optical fiber draw towers and optical fibre preform fabrication lathes, along with their subsequent maintenance over the years, thus contributing meaningfully to the optical fibre technology evolved on site, from ‘bench’ R&D, through multiple prototype equipment variants, ultimately blossoming in commercial exploitation of specialty fibre types used in support of multiple opt electronics products out of Paignton, alongside mainstream communications fibre production on the West Road site (prior to sale to Pirelli).

Always with a friendly smile and keen to bring his drafting and engineering skills to bear, it was a privilege and a pleasure to have him as a member of my teams over the second half of his career, where I could rely on Nobby to bring the job through, alongside general maintenance of existing mechanical equipment. He was an accomplished ‘old school’ Draftsman (pre-CAD).

In his retirement, he worked with offenders as a ‘community service supervisor’, devising and supervising handy-craft rehabilitation projects.

In more recent years he has especially enjoyed working up at Duxford, with volunteer engineer teams, reconstructing and maintaining vintage aircraft at the Airfield Museum where his engineering workshop skills and experience obviously made him the perfect candidate; I know he contributed to resurrection of the Airspeed ‘Ambassador’ airliner, currently on display.

He also belonged to boules and choral groups.

Sincere commiserations to Norman’s friends and family.

Gary Sapsford

Nobby was a great guy and one of the last of his kind. He was an outstanding intuitive technician who could design and fix anything mechanical. The success of the fibre groups in Harlow owes a lot to him. He was an inspiration in my early days at Harlow when were trying to make fibres from fluorides and other exotic glasses. One could always rely on him to be cheerful and optimistic and see the funny side of any circumstance.

Mike Scott

“It’s all part of life’s rich pattern “ – Nobby’s comforting response when our experiments didn’t quite work out, despite his perfect realisation of what was intended by our imperfect specifications. For a young graduate (that’s a long time ago☹️), he was a great steadying influence, and then became a good friend and colleague. Nobby didn’t often complain, although during his extended spell installing the first optical fibre production facility at SEL Stuttgart, he did struggle with the limited availability of traditional English food: engineers arriving for commissioning tasks were required to take a stock of baked beans to keep him going. Sad times, but happy memories.

Garth Lamb

I echo all the comments about what a great person Nobby was to us younger engineers. His knowledge, capability and advice he made freely available to us all at STL, and he was a key enabler of all the fibre optic technology we developed together. As far as the baked beans are concerned, having transported them in the car to Stuttgart doing my stint commissioning equipment and processes, I wonder following Brexit whether we would be able to do so today? We spent many happy hours in the weeks at SEL in both work and leisure times. Visiting Munch Olympic stadium, watching a football game with Bayern Munich & Borussia Mönchengladbach, and Werner the SEL engineer showing us the night life! We even played a game against the cable engineers. We had been billeted by SEL at the rather grand sounding ‘Hotel Schloss Solitude’. Nobby was in ‘permanent’ residence and we other engineers travelled to do rotas with him during the installation phase. It was an old Schloss outside of Stuttgart in the countryside, where they locked the main door at about 9.30pm. I remember one night after a days trekking we got back later at night, Werner/Uli offered to launder Nobbys trousers which were by then sopping wet. Nobby whipped them off, they drove away before the door was open, then a rather sleepy, but startled, night porter opened the door to see his group of strange English guests, one trouserless, asking for entry! We were the talking point for days afterwards. Those were the days!

John Irven

I remember Nobby with affection. I joined Phil Black’s team in 1979 with Garth Lamb working on the development of the Optical Fibre draw towers and the fibre coating technology. As a recent graduate, Nobby was the perfect support to channel my enthusiasm into reality. He had a fabulous temperament that enabled him to work with all sorts of characters. He had patience, knowledge and experience that enabled the team to succeed in its mechanical endeavours. I remember when we (Garth Lamb, Gordon Bolton and John (surname escapes me)) first started working on the towers to be sited in P building. We went through a draft assembly process (that Nobby insisted upon) with the towers horizontal. This enabled us to iron out any issues before we started lifting things into place vertically. There were numerous discussions over coffee which I hadn’t realised were very instrumental in planning the activities so that things ran smoothly. I learnt a lot about how to get things done with Nobby and the team, mostly in terms of people interactions. Nobby helped me with all of the mechanical design and fixings for the first UV Coating installations, all of which worked first time. Nobby worked with many craftsmen in the workshop, most of my work was delivered by Peter Swan. I had not realised until later in my career that things working first time was not always how it worked out! I remember Nobby showing unbelievable patience with a very impatient and driven graduate who wanted to shortcut the design process. They learnt mutual respect after the experience. As you have said, Nobby contributed greatly to the evolution of the technology which, in the case of UV coating process, was successfully transferred to West Road. It was also clear in the coffee sessions that Nobby was a caring individual who spoke about his family with affection. He did have a good sense of humour and I understand that Nobby provided some of the mechanical fixings that helped to stich me up in my pre wedding works stag session at the Gate in Sawbridegworth. Please send my wishes to Ann and the rest of the family at this sad time.

Paul Tomlinson

My recollections of Nobby were that he was always helpful, and knew his way around every mechanical assembly challenge, or workshop practice, you were likely to ask him about. When he was close to retirement we were in the throes of the last days of the components activity in Harlow. He and I spoke of the future, and what was being lost, but Nobby was characteristically optimistic… he showed me his blue-prints for a one eighth-scale steam engine for ride-on mini-tracks. His intention was to make this himself, over his retirement, and see it run on a track that one of his friends/acquaintances had locally. As always this was drawn-up plans (no need for CAD!), and his discussion included how he would tackle such things as the boiler manufacture (pressure-vessel), the hard steels used in running gear, and the optimal selection of materials for every part. In short a brief master-class in engineering from the ground-up. I have often wondered over the subsequent years if he ever built the engine(?). He was one of the central characters in my whole experience of the various incarnations of the Harlow labs, from 1984 through 2001. His anecdotes about his time as an apprentice, and his cheerful denigration of latter day training was a constant delight… and something I carried on to Cambridge with me. Often ruing that I could not turn to his expertise when work-shops there were in quandaries. He will be missed, but remembered fondly.

Terry Clapp

Nobby was a close friend and colleague at STL and made a very significant contribution to the optical fibre programme over several years.

I believe we met first in the late 60’s when I was working on photosensitive materials for copiers and radiography on behalf of SEL Nuremberg. Les Greatbatch and I were building test gear for SEL and needed Model Shop support frequently, which meant Nobby for much of the time.

On completion of that project Charlie Sandbank asked me to take on a challenge to find a way of making optical fibre based on silica glass to complement work already well advanced with the double crucible process in glasses which required lower processing temperatures. One of the first challenges was to pull fibres at the very high temperatures. Nobby joined me and together we built a rudimentary rig using oxy-hydrogen flames to soften silica rods and an ambitious drum winder capable of taking several km of silica fibre. We showed that long lengths of relatively uniform fibre could be produced on this kit, which was then used to produce liquid core fibres by generating a tubular silica fibre and leaving Robin Worthington the task of filling the tube with a suitable refractive index liquid. This type of fibre and plastic clad silica helped with measurement techniques.

The next phase of silica fibre development combined the expertise of John Irven, then in Eric Bush’s group studying vapour deposition, to create doped silica layers on the inside of high purity silica tubes, with our experience of making fibre. We realised that producing a solid rod from the tube before pulling would make the process more controlled, so Nobby and I began experimenting with an old lathe set up in a converted toilet between E and S blocks. We came up with a working solution and then recognised in conjunction with John and Paul Lighty, our consultant, that with slight adaptation the same kit could be used for both the coating and consolidation processes. Nobby was quickly tasked with construction of robust lathe systems and a new pulling tower to take the programme forward. Within months we had the first results outside the USA of a viable low loss fibre making process, and a world first patent.

I have given more detail than normal but wanted to stress that Nobby was an integral part of the team and his work played a crucial role in enabling STL to achieve a world class position in fibre development.

Subsequently the team grew quickly and took on the challenge of making research progress while setting up technology transfers to STC Optical Fibre Unit, SEL in Stuttgart and EOPD in Roanoke. Nobby was a key player in these transfers.

It was interesting that Gary mentioned his departure to be a publican. We regretted his going but welcomed him back when it did not work out, and he fitted back instantly into the wider group.

Nobby was a delight to work with, always positive with a ‘can do’ attitude, keen to learn and able to contribute over a wide spectrum for the benefit of the team.

He will not be forgotten.

Phil Black

Brian Edwards 10th Jan. 2021

Very sorry to hear about Brian Edwards passing. He was my boss for several years and I recall very well having meetings with him – they were scheduled and timed exactly – when your 15 minutes was up the meeting ended!

Brian had had many roles in STC and covered a large range of technologies

As Peter Selway has said he was absolutely invaluable in keeping the QCC going at a time when it was out of favour with the new management

I was honoured to take over as President of the organisation from him. Best wishes to all members.

Ian Vance

Sad news. Brian was one of those scientists who was invariably helpful to us PR hacks (it will surprise you to learn that not all were!), not least when we launched the Hitchin-Stevenage 140 Mbits link, for which I made the film /Light Line/ with the assistance of many others including Alan Hartley-Smith. Brian was also a thoroughly nice guy. I went to see him a few years ago – when he was still in his own home – to talk about Alec Reeves of whom he had quite a few memories.

This getting old business has a lot of downsides!

David R

Sad news about Brian Edwards. Over the past few years, I would occasionally find Brian, sitting on a wall in the sun on his constitutional walk up the road from his Care Home in Stansted; and I would stop for a while to chat.

Unfortunately, the current pandemic has restricted my dog-walking route, so I didn’t see him much last year.

I am pleased to say that I counted Brian as a friend as well as my occasional boss in several different roles relating to the Design and Application of VLSI Silicon Chips and their use in the different STC Divisions. Yes, he could be pedantic, but usually for the right reasons, and things got done!

I first met him at Mallinson House, before he took up residence at STL.

Brian eventually became my Mentor in later roles. I have great respect for him, and he helped me a great deal in progressing my career.

Our discussions would sometimes divert into chats about Motor Sport, where we had a joint interest. (His son Rob is now Chief Operating Officer for ‘Andretti Autosport’ in the USA).

Brian was instrumental in reviving and expanding the STL QCC after the demise of Nortel; and he will be sadly missed.

Colin Jeffrey

Sad news indeed. Brian was also my boss for a few years and as you say he could be pedantic at time but for all the good reasons. He certainly was one of the major motivators in getting the STL QCC going again and what a great success that has been. I’ve not seen him for some years now but understand his health deteriorated somewhat in recent times. I had no idea he was in a care home.

John Barnes

I am so sad to hear of Brian’s passing. Brian was as an important role model and mentor to me as a young engineer at STL and I counted him as friend. As several colleagues have alluded, Brian was always totally prepared for meetings having made it is business to find out the facts. He was also very thoughtful and considerate of others.

One small anecdote to add to the many; Brian and I along with some others set up a Windsurfing section at STL. The windsurfing boards and a trailer were funded by the company as part of the social facility for employees who were well looked after in these days. Each year we had to negotiate the fees paid to the Sailing club where we were based. Our contact at the sailing club was a tough and experienced negotiator having worked professionally as a fleet buyer and was intent to maximise revenue for the club. I was mostly a bystander in these games of chess, carefully prepared arguments and counter arguments exchanged back and forth until finally agreement was reached. This good tempered exchange was no doubt beyond that really needed but we were all caught up in the moment and I learned a lot about the art of negotiation from Brian which has served me well in life.

Hamish McKinlay

Very sad news indeed. I had the privilege of working alongside Brian in the early 1980’s in the STC Technical Directorate at Mallinson House, Southgate. We both reported to Bernie Mills when he was STC’s Technical Director. Brian was a man of seemingly limitless wisdom and near-infinite patience with far less experienced engineers like me. He taught me a great deal about a lot of things, and I regard my time spent with him and Bernie as the most developmental per unit time of my whole career. We stayed in touch of course – Brian never forgot people and never stopped caring!

Sir David Brown

Very sad news in these difficult times. My time at STL was so short, only ten years, but with the help of Brian STL we achieved great strides in IC technology cumulating with the STC Queen award in 1990. My relationship with the great man was more like I had as a school captain with my former head master, close but strict and formal. He did however let me into his passion of Go cart racing, even allowing my Son to drive his latest creation, armed with an engine with tuned exhaust, high lift cams etc. It has so much power it was too much for Andrew to handle. Brian was caring and very supportive to my son at this time, who eventually thought Landrovers are far safer bet. I do find it is so sad that these wonderful people like Brian are not with us anymore, but their great achievements will live on.

Peter Blomley

Fellow members – I am very sad following Brian’s death. As others have done, you reflect back over your history with someone you have known and respected so much. I reckon I have known Brian since the Autumn of 1965 when I joined STL right up until the present when Brian participated in our weekly Zoom ‘virtual coffee morning’ with a small group of STL friends. It is a privilege to have not just known him over those 55 years, but to have worked with him in our professional capacity, as well as being able to share his ‘extra-curricular’ activities and to be mutually supportive on personal issues too. I remember being introduced to him by Ken Matthews as we went off at lunchtimes to the centre of the STL universe – the canteen! That’s where friendships were forged and tough technical issues solved at the same time. Brian was one of those great people who was eminently trustworthy in the deepest meaning of that word. For me, if I had a problem be it professional or personal, then I knew Brian would listen and help if he could. Likewise, if Brian asked me a question or for help I would have no hesitation in responding positively because he was such a great person. With his passing my life is the poorer, but my memories are all the richer.

Peter Radley

Gazing now down with a knowing smile,

Helping us all with his modest style.

When about to complement his scheme,

“Time is up” Brian’s eyes indeed will beam.

“Leave taking” adapted from Tolkien’s translation of medieval poem:

Ladies and lords, with beer and wines,

I thank you here and wish you well.

I bless you all a thousand times.

In all you do, may you excel.

As you go by, up hill, down dell,

Pray God help you in all you try.

Let all friends hear the tales you tell.

But as for me, I say goodbye.

…

Goodbye to you both tall and small,

Goodbye to you, men of all kinds.

Goodbye to you, good people all,

I thank you all a thousand times.

For every wish in all your minds.

My will to help will never die.

And pray relax your mental binds.

As now, at last, I say goodbye.

Richard Catchpole

Steve Hazon 26th Dec. 2020

These are my memories of my oldest friend Steve.

Steve and I both spent our very early years in Upchurch, Kent, a village in North Kent on the outskirts of the Medway towns. We both attended Upchurch Infants school in the 1960s. Steve was a year older than me but the village was quite small at the time. Steve lived in Oak Lane and I lived in Chaffes lane. My first memory is of Steve’s mum giving me a tooty frootie at a young age.

When I was 7 or 8 my family moved to Lower Halstow. My brother went to Lower Halstow Infants school and being at the school transfer age I went to Barrow Grove in Sittingbourne. Steve had followed the usual path for those at Upchurch Infants and moved on to Hollywell School just outside the village. Our paths didn’t cross for some time. I passed the 11 plus and went to Borden Grammar School in Sittingbourne joining in form 1E. Much to my surprise I bumped into Steve who had entered Borden Grammar School in the same academic year joining in form 1X. I found out that Steve had moved on from Hollywell to the local secondary school Westlands. After only one year there he was declared to be “too bright” for the school and a result was sent on to Grammar school. After the first year at Borden Grammar, we were streamed and both ended up in form 2A and continued in the top class up the school. I can’t recall what O level choices Steve made. Remaining at Borden (no 6th form Colleges then), we both started A levels in the Lower Sixth Science doing the same subjects – Physics, Maths, and Chemistry (there weren’t that many to choose from). Steve will have had memories of our Maths teacher (and form teacher) Bob Sutton, Physics – John Hearn and John Macrae, and our Chemistry Teacher Bob Ladds. In our final year we gained the red tie as school prefects with Wally Weekes as our form master.

During our school days, Steve wasn’t my only friend nor I his. Our paths crossed often and we shared many common interests. During those teenage years I recall meddling with old valve radios to put them into service as amplifiers. We were both interested in electronics which at that time wasn’t taught at schools. Everyday Electronics was a popular magazine at the time and Steve built an electric bass guitar in his garage. Later, we ran a disco but were probably more interested in the electronics (and very dodgy/dangerous sound to light system we built) than the music.

Somehow, we both ended up at the same university – Royal Holloway College University of London at Egham. This wasn’t deliberate at all and I don’t recall how it came about. We both studied Physics and had fairly separate groups of friends – through the College was quite small (less than 2000) at that time so most people new all the others at least by sight. Steve will recall Pete Richardson and Steve Warr who were studying physics at the same time and another of my friends Meredydd Jones. In the first year Steve was resident in Williamson Hall which had the benefit of being on the campus and having a very limited kitchen (rare at RHC at that time) – so we often used to meet there at lunch between lectures consuming tinned soup, bread rolls taken at breakfast and broken biscuits bought from a local forerunner to pound shops in Egham. In out third year Steve met Louise, also studying at RHC and they became engaged. At that time Steve had acquired his first car a Morris Minor and Lesley Richardson (nee Riley) recalls Steve and Louise proudly driving around the campus.

We left RHC in 1980. Steve joined STL in Harlow and I went to Nottingham to do another year’s study in Electronics. We stayed in contact and a result of his good experience in his first job amongst my other applications I applied to STL as well. I was accepted (Steve must have put in a good word) and decided I’d join as well.

So, I started working for STL in Sept 1981 joining Industrial and Automotive products working for Stan Allen. Our group were based in building Z1 and the team included Steve Frankland, Andy Leftley, Terry Stock, Keith ??, Dave ?? and our lab tech. Tom (Gizzard) Bailey. I recall that our department number was R402 (I still have a few tools marked as such oops!), and that the big boss was Jon Bagley. At that time STC (of which STL was the research centre) was owned by ITT and we worked on R&D projects for all of the ITT companies from whom a Research levy was drawn. The projects I recall from the time were Automotive multiplex for SWF, Windscreen Wiper manufacturing fault detection, Vortex shedding flowmeters, Programmable pump controllers for Loewe. At some point we were re-organised within STL and became part of a larger team working on largely on defence products under Dr Phil Hargraves. A number of studies and research stuff was going on and one big project arose which was the GPS receiver project resulting eventually in the STR 2515 GPS Navigation System, the first PPS device outside of the USA. This was a really big project thought I must confess I can’t recall what part Steve played in it. Times were changing and STL/STC was now merged with ICL. Thomas Meirion Jackson (aka Jackie or Tom) 1921 – 2018

Jackie was born in Dolgllau, Wales, and as a boy moved to Corwen. He left school at 16 and worked as a Junior in a solicitor’s office until he was conscripted into the RAF in 1940. After a period in London, Jackie was posted to TRE (later renamed RSRE) Malvern to work on Oboe, an aerial blind bomb targeting system, based on radio transponder technology. The lead researcher of Oboe was Alec Reeves who after WW2 joined STL in Enfield. Jackie had his personal Wellington bomber for testing the developing Oboe equipment, and stayed at TRE until he joined STL at Enfield in 1946.

Between 1948 and 1958 he developed multi-electrode cold cathode switching tubes for performing logic and memory functions. Once developed the devices were manufactured by STC Valve Division in Paignton until about 1970. The devices were used in the first UK commercial digital mainframe computer, LEO.

In 1958 Jackie and his team moved to the new Harlow site and began to develop millimetre wave reflex klystron tubes for long-haul waveguide communication systems. The frequency range of the klystrons was 20 to 120 GHz, and the design was transferred for manufacture at ITT Electron Tube Division in Easton, Pa. The klystrons were used as a pump for a parametric amplifier in the first UK satellite communication system built at Goonhilly Down, Cornwall, in the early 1960s.

Klystron development finished at STL in 1965 and Jackie’s area started work on developing computer-controlled micro-engraving for the precision adjustment of thin film circuits. The technology was transferred to STC Components in Paignton, where it was used until the mid 1980s.

Between 1968 and 1985 Jackie’s department worked on a range of technologies:

Setting up an n-channel MOS processing facility in STL, and applying the process to the design and fabrication of a ‘cross point’ switching chip for PABX and a shift register for TXE4A. This was the first n-channel process in Europe and gave ITT and advantageous position in switching systems.

Setting up a bipolar semiconductor processing facility at STL for the design and development of high performance transistors for STC Submarine Systems Division.

Developing advanced semiconductor processing technology based on plasma processing. One of the key processes developed was the plasma etching of the aluminium metallization on silicon wafers, whereby channels 1 micron wide and 2 microns deep could etched with vertical walls. The process was licensed to an equipment company and was subsequently adopted by the major semiconductor companies.

Setting up a design and processing facility for the selective etching of single crystal silicon to form micro-miniature pressure sensors and accelerometers.

Development of a disc switch for ITT Relay Division, Harlow, leading to the manufacture of 20 million units in 1984.

Jackie retired in 1985 with 64 patents to his name, and his department, minus the semiconductor device processing which he had relinquished in 1982, was passed to Dr Peter Graves, forming the Advanced Materials Technology Department. The plasma process was developed into the unique pulsed plasma process which enabled novel materials to be deposited at room temperature. The process attracted government and SDI funding. Likewise the micro-machined silicon structures were developed into a novel vibrating pressure sensor, which was licensed to Druck, and an accelerometer capable of being used in ordinance.

Jackie was proud of his Welsh roots and was active in local Welsh-speaking clubs. His patriotism came to a head each year when Wales played England at rugby. His daughter recalled at his funeral that when Wales beat England she was given a 6d (2½p) coin, and he would telephone his friends to ask what they thought of the game! Rudolf August Heinecke (1935-2017)

Rudolf graduated in electrical engineering from the Staaliche Ingenieur Schule in Ulm and then in Physics from the Technischer Ingenieur Schule in Hannover in 1959. He then joined AEG-Telefunken in Ulm, where he worked on the processing of thin film integrated circuit technology. In 1966 he joined STL, attracted by reports from a former AEG colleague, Theo Rutgers, of exciting, groundbreaking work going on in the laboratories. He joined Jackie Jackson’s department and continued his work on developing thin film circuit technology.

About 1970 he started work on the use of plasmas in materials processing, and his first development was to etch channels in thin aluminium films of the type used in silicon chips. The results were remarkable as the channels were 1 micron wide and 2 microns deep, with vertical walls. This was a major advance in etching the aluminium metallization, as at the time the aluminium was wet-etched, resulting in poor definition and undercut channels.

Also in the 1970s, Rudolf developed a process for depositing aluminium-silicon alloys and silicon nitride onto silicon chips, the latter to passivate the chip from corrosive atmospheres. These developments and the plasma etching of aluminium were patented and licensed to equipment manufacturers. They are in use worldwide today in the semiconductor industry.

When Jackie retired in 1985, his department was transferred to my area and renamed Advanced Materials Technology. Soon after, Rudolf and David Carter developed a selective plasma etching process for single crystal quartz, whereby the central region of a quartz blank, 0.5 mm thick, could be etched to 16.7 microns in order to make a 100 MHz resonator.

Rudolf was aware that one of the limitations of the plasma deposition process he had developed was the need to heat the substrate onto which a material was being deposited. So he and Suresh Ojha came up with the concept of using very short pulses of high power radiofrequency energy, about 50 kW, synchronized with pulsed inputs of gases. Using this unique concept, equipment was designed and built by members of Rudolf’s team: Ian Llewellyn, Geoff Scarsbrook, Keith Sheach and Rab Chittick. Many materials were deposited using pulsed plasma, such as thin films of diamond, ablation resistant coatings for infrared missile windows, germanium phosphide-sulphide films and complex multilayer structures to reflect laser radiation. The latter was funded by the American Strategic Defense Initiative (aka Star Wars) programme intiated by President Reagen.

Around 1990, Rudolf took on a project on silicon microengineering that remained after the bulk of the work had been licensed to Druck Ltd. In 1992 Rudolf’s group transferred to John Leach’s department, but due to funding problems and lack of interest by Nortel in the work, the team started to disperse and Rudolf retired in 1996.

Rudolf was a great lateral thinker and invented new ways for processing materials. He energized members of his team to develop his concepts and to discover their own techniques to achieve world firsts. As a result of all his work and that of his team, Rudolf was awarded over 40 patents, and co-authored a number of scientific papers. He was presented with the prestigious STL Joe Evans Memorial Award for his exceptional creativity. He was well known and respected by his colleagues at STL, thirteen of whom attended his funeral on 14th November.

Now a couple of light-hearted stories about Rudolf’s command of English, which he spoke with a slight German accent that could be mistaken for an English dialect. On one occasion he and I were in a meeting with two German engineers from SEL Stuttgart. The meeting was conducted in English, but at one point the two engineers carried out a long conversation in German. When they finished, Rudolf said something in German to them. They were surprised at Rudolf’s command of their language. When he told them it was his mother tongue, they were most embarrassed, and didn’t break into German again!!

The other incident occurred at a conference he attended, where there was simultaneous translation from a speaker’s mother tongue into English. A German speaker launched into his talk, with the English translation over headphones. Suddenly the translation stopped, and after some time Rudolf called out in German “A verb, a verb, please a verb!” because the translator couldn’t continue the translation because the speaker hadn’t got to the verb at the end of a sentence!

ROGER JAMES WILLIAMSON (1947 – 2015)

Physicist, Inventor and Thespian

Roger Williamson graduated in Physics from UCL and joined STL in 1968. He worked on electromechanical channel filters under Albert Russen, and in 1972 he joined my Passives & Hybrids Dept to work on integrated crystal filters under Tony Truelove. The aim was to reduce the number of individual quartz resonators used in channel filters by integrating as many resonators on a single piece of quartz. Tony and Roger developed a triple pole resonator, involving some complex mathematics, and Quartz Crystal Division (QCD) then set the task of developing a control system to enable the resonators to achieve pre-set frequencies during the process of depositing the silver electrodes. Roger undertook this task with his usual enthusiasm, utilising his knowledge of electronics, and built an experimental system to control the deposition of the three pairs of resonators, and integrated it into a piece of production equipment. To achieve this he spent many weeks at QCD, and successfully demonstrated the system to QCD management and the STL group.

Another memory of Roger’s contribution to QCD at Leeds, concerned the metallisation of blocks of glass and the bonding of wafers of PZT (lead zirconate titanate) to it by soldering. The blocks of glass were to be used as glass delay lines, and after soldering on the PZT, the block was cut into a series of thin slices using a multiple-blade saw. Problems had arisen with the deposition of the metallisation on the glass block and subsequent soldering, and Roger was able to improve the process using his expertise gained from the bonding of PZT to electromechanical filters that he had worked on in his first days at STL.

Henley F. Sterling (1919-2012)

Self-taught engineer and born inventor.

I recently learnt from his son Derek that Henley died in December 2012, in a nursing home in Bexhill-on-Sea. I have been in touch with some of his former colleagues at STL, and the following is a compilation of all our memories of him.

Henley was born in London and as a child showed a flair for experimentation. He told me that he burnt the counterpane on his bed with sodium he had electrolysed using the DC mains supplied to his home, and blew off the cast iron surround of the fireplace in his bedroom with black powder he prepared from readily available chemicals! When he left school at 14 or 15 he worked for a chemical company making cosmetics and perfumes, as he could not continue with further education due to family circumstances. When WW2 was declared he joined the RAF and was trained as a Radar Engineer on the CHL (Chain Home Low) system. He was posted to radar stations at Swingate on the cliffs at Dover, experimental units in the UK and West Africa (on the way his ship was torpedoed and he was one of the few survivors). He ended up in Europe after D-day with a unit detecting the launching of V2s from mobile sites by triangulation, so Typhoon fighters could be scrambled to destroy the sites.

After WW2 he joined the newly formed STL at Enfield and was involved with initial work on silicon made from silane and the single crystal growth of silicon. Later he applied the RF expertise gained in the RAF to developing, with Reg Warren, a method of melting conducting materials without contamination in a water-cooled crucible – the so-called silver boat process. The molten metal was micro-levitated by the RF power in a coil around the silver boat, and the metal could be zone-refined by passing the boat through the coil. The process was initially used to purify and grow single crystal silicon, although his manager Jack Wilson had forbad him using any of the stock of silane-silicon! Later he applied the silver boat process to melting refractory metals and compounds, e.g. tungsten (mpt 3422oC) and zirconium diboride (mpt 3246oC). For his work in this area, he received an award from ITT.

In the early 1960s, Henley applied his RF techniques to the plasma deposition of amorphous silicon, silicon oxide and silicon nitride. He built up a world-leading team, which included John Alexander, Dick Swann, Sadie Hughes and Rab Chittick. The processes the team developed were applied to semiconductor processing, e.g. the passivation of devices with silicon nitride.

Henley then threw his energies to developing new materials and processes for electrolytic capacitors, and their failure mechanisms, with a team including Dick Humphries, Sadie Hughes and Miles Drake, managed by Eric Bush.

Henley was a front-line scientist with boundless enthusiasm and had numerous patents; he did not seek to be a manager, but became a Chief Principal Research Engineer until he retired in 1984. In retirement he spent his time researching his family history, finding ancestors who were Huguenots and goldsmiths in London, between 1770 and 1750.

Many people owe Henley a great deal, and he had quite an influence on the development of their careers and hence their lives. Regrettably none of his former colleagues were aware of his death a year ago and so were unable to pay their last respects at his funeral – only six family members were present.

Dr Peter Graves
